CyberLink PowerDVD Ultra 9 is a nice universal player with Blu-Ray support that I?ve used a lot in the past. That being said, there is a superior universal player called ArcSoft TotalMedia Theatre 3 also with Blu-Ray support. It can even play Blu-Ray M2TS with DTS audio which is impossible with PowerDVD. 

After discovering ArcSoft TotalMedia Theatre 3 I uninstalled PowerDVD. I suggest trying them both.

http://thepiratebay.org/torrent/5225442/Blu-Ray_Player_Arcsoft_TotalMedia_Theatre_Platinum_3___Updates

For playing high-definition content, TotalMedia Theatre 3 is a great player, but it is'nt if you want to watch a DVD on an high-res screen with with the SimHD Plug-in. SimHD is ArcSoft's upscaling technology, turning standard-definition multimedia files and DVDs into high-definition ones, and it's very bad compared with CyberLink's TrueTheater technology.

If you can't play Blu-Ray M2TS with DTS audio, try update 2320:

* CyberLink PowerDVD is now optimized for ATI Radeon HD 5000 series graphics cards.
* Includes DTS-HD Master Audio and Dolby TrueHD with lossless output, for extra high quality Blu-ray playback via High-resolution Audio with 

HDMI HD-Audio pass-through.
* Now supports TrueTheater HD with CUDA on NVIDIA ION platforms.

Issues resolved:
* Noise during LPCM DVD playback.

ADHDerby:

I just installed PowerDVD Ultra 9 2320 and tried playing Casino Royale M2TS with DTS and the audio stuttered and was unwatchable.

Would you really want PowerDVD Ultra 9 or TotalMedia 3 for anything other than High-Definition content? I've always just used VLC player. I guess upscaling is a good reason but I've never tried it.

It's the main reason why I use it. The TrueTheater effects (TrueTheater HD, TrueTheater Lighting and TrueTheater Motion) are top notch.
About the stuttering: have you installed the latest audio drivers?

Thanks for the upload but this did not work for me. I kept getting an error on startup stating that my graphics card (on my fairly new W7 system) was incompatible. I checked with the Cyberlink website which stated that my graphics card *was* compatible. The downloadable compatibility checker also gave it the green light. I uninstalled it and tried ArcSoft TotalMedia Theatre 3 as suggested, which worked like a breeze.
